newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EMU to aid mortgage market but obstacles remain.
newsitem.headline: EMU to aid mortgage market but obstacles remain.

text.p: A single European currency will help create a harmonised mortgage market for consumers, but national taxation differences are likely to hinder complete integration, the European Mortgage Federation said on Thursday.

At a news conference outlining its annual report, officials from the federation said sharp differences in the deductibility of mortgage interest payments within the 15-nation bloc was perhaps the greatest obstacle to a common mortgage market.
"The biggest problem is taxation," said Judith Hardt, secretary general of the federation.
"Most countries don't allow you to borrow in another country and at the same time deduct the interest on the mortgage."

In Britain, for example, a borrower entering into a mortgage contract abroad with a company which has no subsidiary in Britain must deduct 20 percent of the interest payments as a payment to the Inland Revenue.
In Portugal and Spain, if borrowers pay their mortgage interest to a foreign institution, the payments are subject to a 10 percent withholding tax.
The upshot of these differences, said Hardt, is that borrowers risk a number of pitfalls when venturing outside their countries in search of cheaper mortgage rates.
A single currency should help expose such differences and prompt greater competition among financial institutions.
Over time a more competitive environment coupled with greater convergence in interest rates among EMU members could potentially diminish market distortions, she added.
The federation said it supported the European Commission's efforts to achieve greater tax harmonisation among governments ahead of the single currency's planned launch in 1999.
